About 3 years ago,\. I decided that I wanted to challenge
myself.\. I've always wanted to write music for video
games,\. and have messed with some ideas in the past, but
never actually composed anything very meaningful.
Here was the challenge.\. My sister would send me images
or drawings of settings or characters, and I would create
a theme for that setting or character.\. I used FL Studio
to create all of my compositions.
The first piece I wrote during the challenge was
Desertown.\. I composed a total of seventeen musical
pieces for the challenge, experimenting with different
sounds and keys and time signatures.
You can see all the songs I wrote for the challenge at the
artist's house at the top left of Desertown.\. I would have
put them here,\. but I had already programmed that house
and decided it would be a better place for them.
After the challenge was over, I was inspired to keep writing
music.\. After composing a few more battle themes,\. I toyed
with the idea of developing my own video game based on the
music I composed for each setting and character.
For some reason, I had downloaded RPG Maker MZ to my
computer.\. I guess I thought it might be fun to play
around with as an elementary game developing engine.
I went through the tutorial for the software,\. figured
out how everything worked together,\. and realized that
I could definitely make something cool with it.\. All I
needed was a story.
I suddenly found myself typing up a script.\. I worked on
it hours a day for about three days.\. I wanted it to be a
little serious, but also lighthearted and self-aware.\. It
had a basic plot,\. but I was proud of what I wrote.
After that I started the development process.\. I grossly
underestimated the amount of time it would take me to
develop my vision, though.\. At first,\. I calculated that
I could finish developing the game within three months.
And perhaps that could theoretically be possible if I never
had to sleep, eat, work, attend university, visit my family,
and was just a machine that could work nonstop for three
months straight.
No,\. this game took me over two years to finish in its
entirety.\. I didn't work on it every day during that two
years,\. but I seriously had to have put thousands of
hours into its development time.
During the challenge, my sister gave me pictures of two
cartoon animals that I thought I could be turned into
good party members that would join the player.\. Those
animals became Henriko and \N[4].
I decided to do a twist on a familiar trope.\. You know how
RPGs usually have one or two animals mixed in with a crew
of human characters?\. For my RPG, there would be one human,\.
and the rest of the party would be animals.
That means I needed a third animal character that would
join with the player.\. I had been playing a lot of
Animal Crossing that summer.\. It was the perfect game
to relax with during the whole COVID pandemic freakout.
My favorite villager in Animal Crossing is Mathilda the
kangaroo.\. So I thought, "what the heck? I'll just make
the other animal a kangaroo villager." So against my better
judgment, I started spriting a bunch of bootleg kangaroos.
I pretty much copied Nintendo's homework. I colored them
differently from their AC counterparts and gave them
different names,\. but you can obviously tell that
Kate is Kitt,\. Sabrina is Sylvia,\. et cetera.
If any problems arise from what I've done,\. like if
Nintendo's ninjas come after me,\. I won't fight them.\.
I'll just take the game back and redesign the kangaroos
so that they're somewhat more original.
Anyway,\. the kangaroo was the third animal character.\.
I thought they were a good fit.\. They matched the other
character's cuteness factors well.
But that wasn't enough for me.\. I wanted to challenge
myself to take it one step further.\. I gave the player
the option to choose from one of three different kangaroos
depending on which kangaroos house they stayed at.
Writing dialogue for each of them was surprisingly difficult
and time-consuming.\. I copy and pasted a lot from my script,\.
but there was still a lot of extra dialogue I needed to
write during development.
And I didn't want them to be animals just for the sake of
being animals.\. I gave them special abilities that made
use of what their animal's species were known for.
For example, there are certain areas where Henriko had to
leap across green squares to solve a puzzle,\. and several
small holes that \N[3] could send little \N[5] through.\.
Best I could do for the wizard was burning trees.
I created all of the sprites for the frogs, the kangaroos,
and the wizard.\. Character sprites, face sprites, and battle
sprites.\. I created eight player characters in RPG Maker's
character creator for the player to choose from.
For the enemy monsters,\. I took a lot of inspiration
from old toys and old drawings that my sister drew when
she was younger.\. I put more thought into some enemies
and less thought into others.
I created all of the sprites for the Benefic Four, The
Benefactor, and the LEACH,\. except for Squidusa,\. who
was designed by my sister.
I had already composed Hygluk's battle theme, Squidusa's
themes, and Enriqué's first battle theme during the
challenge.\. I later composed Garskamar's, The Benefactor's,
and the LEACH's themes.
I bet you're wondering about The Shadow Thief, aren't you?\.
I loved the Mario & Luigi series growing up, and I was
saddened to hear that we might not be getting anymore now
that the company who develops them has gone bankrupt.
So I wanted to give the Shadow Thief, arguably the best
character from Superstar Saga,\. one last role in a game,\.
since it's very likely we'll never ever see him again in
one of Nintendo's games.
Although,\. at the time of me writing this,\. the remake
for Super Mario RPG: Legend of the Seven Stars is coming
out soon,\. so I guess anything is possible.
And of course,\. if Nintendo finds out about me putting
their character in my game and orders me to take it down,\.
I'll just replace The Shadow Thief with some boring, old
character who is not as cool as The Shadow Thief.
At one point during production,\. I had to replace my
computer,\. because my old computer was having trouble
keeping a charge,\. and I didn't want to take the risk
of losing all of my hard work.
I'm sure that's a huge fear for a lot of programmers out
there.\. Losing everything.\. Luckily,\. I was able to
save all of my work without a problem.
Another reason development took so long is because I had
so many ideas that arised during development that I wanted
to implement.\. Some of these ideas were fishing, Henriko's
Scout move,\. and the Minimon battle with Eunice.
I never at first even intended for Monsterville to be an
area in the game.\. Originally you would have fought the
SHADESTER somewhere in the Cave of Darkness Unending.\.
I think all I did was worth it in the end.
My only regret is that I could not make the final battle
with the LEACH creepier than it already is.\. I had this
grandiose vision of slimy, disgusting, monochrome textures
and even more horrifying facial expressions.
That aside,\. I think I made a pretty cool game.
And it's free!\. I don't want to charge anything for my
first amateur passion project game. By the way,\. if you
were forced to spend any money to download this game,\.
you were scammed.
But even though I think the game is cool,\. I'm not the
judge.\. That title goes to you, the player.\. What did
you think of Hero's Advent?
It's not perfect.\. I'm sure there are some bugs that I
missed somewhere.\. I'm also aware of a few bugs that I'm
not sure I'll be able to fix.
If you'd like to report a bug you find anywhere,\. please
reach out to the real Jorel somehow.\. I'd love to
eventually find all of the bugs and fix them for future
versions of the game.
And now,\. I'm finally happy to say that I am done with
Hero's Advent.\. I've finally completed the game I've
worked for more than two years on.\. And now I can
share it with the world.

Frogs
The frogs, huh?\. One day, my sister challenged me to
compose a theme song for a silly little frog in a jester
hat.\. Later, she wanted me to compose a battle theme
for a frog in a black jacket and pompadoured hair.
From these two frogs,\. the characters Henriko and Enriqué
came to be.\. I decided to make them brothers,\. one on the
side of the hero, and one on the dark side that would
challenge the heroes often.
Frog Town was the last area I implemented in the game.\.
You should only be able to get there after you've saved
the world.\. Not before.
Kangaroos
Henriko and the wizard were characters based off of images
that my sister showed me, both animals.\. To keep with the
theme,\. I wanted another animal character to join
the hero on their quest for an even four party members.
So I decided to take inspiration from Animal Crossing and
create a bunch of bootleg kangaroo villagers.\. You can
choose from one of three kangaroos to join you on the
adventure.\. You chose \N[3].\. Good choice.
Later,\. I implemented a way to upgrade \N[3]'s hammer.\.
You can upgrade it up to three times.\. It took a little
work to make the hammer appear different each time it was
upgraded,\. but it was worth it.
Also,\. originally,\. \N[3] could wear whatever armor
she wanted,\. but I thought it would be cooler if there
were specific pieces of armor that only she could wear.\.
Did you find all of them?

The wizard, huh?\. One day, my sister showed me a study
of a fox,\. appearing to float,\. wearing a purple cape
or cloak of some sort.\. From this image, the wizard
character was born.
I couldn't think of any good names for them.\. That's why
I gave the player the opportunity to name the wizard
themselves.
Also,\. did you know that there are three different wizards
that could possibly join you?\. But it's completely random
which wizard you'll get.\. Looks like you got the fox.\.
Pretty cool.
Also,\. did you know that there are three different wizards
that could possibly join you?\. But it's completely random
which wizard you'll get.\. Looks like you got the rabbit.\.
Pretty cool.
Also,\. did you know that there are three different wizards
that could possibly join you?\. But it's completely random
which wizard you'll get.\. Looks like you got the bear.\.
Pretty cool.
The Shadow Thief
The Shadow Thief?\. If you enjoy Nintendo's Mario & Luigi RPG
series,\. you can probably tell that The Shadow Thief is
not my character.
But I couldn't help including him in my game.\. I guess I
thought it was unfair that such a great character might
not get any screentime ever again since the company that
develops the Mario & Luigi games has gone bankrupt.
So,\. I found a sprite sheet online for him and got to work.\.
In order to avoid as much legal trouble as I could,\. I
changed the colors of his outfit and refrained from saying
his true name at all times.
The only time you can see his name is in the credits when
I credit the original composer of his battle theme.\. If
trouble does arise from me essentially breaking copyright
laws,\. I'll replace the Shadow Thief with another guy.

The Benefic Four
The Benefic Four?\. First is Hygluk.
One day, my sister challenged me to write a battle theme for
a boss character.\. The boss character was a huge zombie
monster wielding a giant axe.\. I didn't take much
inspiration from that creature when designing Hygluk.
I made him sort of a tragic character, didn't I?\. Anyway,\.
that's Hygluk.\. Next is Squidusa.
My sister challenged me to write themes for an image of
an octopus-esque woman.\. Later,\. when I started with
development,\. I asked my sister if she wanted to design
her own squid woman to be in my game.
She came up with the name, Squidusa.\. In fact,\. my sister
came up with the names for Henriko, Enriqué, and Hygluk as
well.\. I came up with Garskamar, though.
In fact,\. Garskamar's been an idea of mine for a while.\.
Originally,\. I wasn't planning on adding Garskamar to this

going to just be some random black knight character.
I think Garskamar was a much better choice.\. He's a good
fit for this game.
The SHADESTER
One day, my sister gave me an image of a cloaked alien
creature and challenged me to write a battle theme for
it.\. The SHADESTER was inspired by that image.
Originally,\. I wasn't going to do much with the SHADESTER.\.
You would just fight him somewhere in the Cave of Darkness
Unending,\. but then I had the idea for Monsterville and
everything fell into place.
The Benefactor/LEACH
The Benefactor was my attempt at making a smiley face a
villain.\. I gave the smiley face a body,\. a motivation,\.
plot importance,\. a dark secret,\. and there you have
it.
The LEACH was sort of symbolism for all of my bottled up
hatred and anxiety.\. I meant to channel all of my hate
into the creature,\. but I found that difficult to do
because I don't really have much hate in my life.
Still,\. I hope you feel better finally being able to
defeat it.\. I know it means nothing,\. but maybe that
thing won't hold us back so much from now on.
Mr. P
Have you met Mr. P?\. Mr. P is not my character.\. He is
my sister's character.\. In fact,\. I was really taking
a risk putting him in this game.\. My sister has big plans
for a future project of hers starring him.
She really loves this project of hers,\. and we've had
conversations around her question,\. "what if my project
was a video game?"\. So I couldn't help experimenting a
bit and add a little visual novel detour to my game.
For privacy reasons,\. I don't reveal much about Mr. P or
his project,\. just that he's a detective from a world of
monsters.\. If you do things right,\. you can see what he
looks like at a very specific moment.
My sister is totally supportive of this,\. and we can just

alluding to this game in her project, so we'll see.
Speaking of which,\. look out for "Mr. P. P_______ and the
Very Unusual Case",\. a webcomic coming to a webcomic
distribution website near you someday.
If by "???",\. you meant the mysterious voice in the Cave

I was going to have it so that they were like "the great
computer program", and that they're whole purpose was to

purpose could be fulfilled,\. but nah.\. I didn't like that.
So, yeah,\. they're just for exposition.\. And for getting
help on where to go next if you need it.\. Other than that,\.
they're useless.

Kangaroo's Houses
So Animal Crossing has this feature where you can play
an "aircheck" of one of K.K. Slider's songs in your house,\.
and I wanted to do something similar for the Kangaroo
Villagers in this game.
I didn't feel like writing an original song for each
kangaroo, though,\. so I took inspiration from some
other existing songs.\. I made my own "aircheck"
versions of them.
I attempted to match each kangaroo with a song that would
fit their personalities.\. In Kate's house, there is a
string arrangement of "Oh, What a Beautiful Morning"
from the musical "Oklahoma".
In Bethina's house,\. it's Bach's Invention No. 4.\.
In Roobie's shop,\. there's a little electric piano
cover of the jazz standard "Take Five".
Fans of The Commodores might have recognized "Brick House"
playing in Sabrina's house.\. If you saved Barbaroo from
Halcyon,\. you'll hear a short arrangement of "Rufus
Xavier Sarsparilla" from Schoolhouse Rock in her school.
I should note that I'm not well versed in copyright law at
all,\. so if I get in any trouble for using covers of
these songs,\. especially for Brick House or Rufus Xavier
Sarsparilla,\. I'll write original songs.
MacRoo is the only kangaroo who received an original theme
song.\. However,\. his theme song was originally a cover
of "Running in the 90s" from "Initial D".\. You may have
recognized it playing in this room right now.
I decided to give MacRoo his own theme because I wanted him
to also have his own boss theme,\. as I wanted him to be
the surprise final challenger of the Tournament in
Technologica.
His original boss theme was going to be this same cover of
"Running in the 90s" with louder instrumentation, but it
sounded so terrible and was hard to listen to,\. so I
just scrapped it and wrote a new battle theme.
I decided to give MacRoo his own song because I had an
idea to do something special with him.
Monsterville and Mr. P
During the challenge,\. my sister challenged me to write
a song inspired by the image of some cute, funky little
critters walking along in a dark forest.\. So I started
to create a song.
However,\. I soon felt like I was getting off track with
what I was writing.\. The funky basslines I was writing
didn't really fit with the whole forest vibe to me,\. so
I put that idea aside and started a fresh song.
I soon completed a decent forest theme that would then
become the theme for The Wandering Woods.\. When it came
to a theme for Monsterville,\. I didn't have any songs
from the challenge at the ready.
But I thought the first idea that I had for the forest theme
would be the perfect fit for Monsterville,\. so I recovered
it from the discard pile and completed what I started,\.
adding more ideas and making it a full-fledged song.
Mr. P's theme song is a similar case.\. My sister challenged
me to write a theme song for one of her characters.\. When
starting to write a theme for Mr. P,\. I liked the ideas
I was coming up with.
But I knew this character was really special to my sister,\.
and the theme I was writing wasn't special enough,\. so I
decided to start over using similar ideas while really
putting feeling into it this time.
I use both versions of Mr. P's theme in the game.\. The
first "beta" version of his theme plays in his house
normally,\. while the full version plays in his house
once you've found a way to help him.
Storming the Castle
This is the song that plays when you are, as the title of
the song says, "Storming the Castle".\. It's a song that's
over seven minutes long,\. incorporating ideas from many
other songs in this game.
I wanted to write a song that would continuously play even
during enemy battles,\. so I wanted it to be a fairly long
song that was always interesting to listen to and wouldn't
get boring too quickly.
I started writing that song the summer of 2022.\. About
3/4 finished with it,\. I was struck with some creative
block and decided to leave it alone for a while before
coming back to it.
Turns out I wouldn't come back to the song until summer
2023.\. Not quite a year from starting it, but close enough
to it.\. I was finally able to finish it at that point.\.
It's over seven and a half minutes long including the intro.
Halcyon's Theme
I used the Digital Audio Workstation FL Studio to compose
most all of the songs in this game.\. However,\. two of
the songs I composed in Garageband.\. These songs play
in the Blacksmith's, and postgame Halcyon.
Several years ago,\. when I was still in high school,\. I
would sometimes open up GarageBand on my now lost forever
iPod touch and compose a few ideas.\. One of these ideas
became what is now the theme for Halcyon.
Fortunately,\. before I lost my iPod,\. I emailed some of
the ideas to myself so I could use or rework them later.\.
So the song you hear in Halcyon is a song I wrote over
five years ago in GarageBand.
The Blacksmith's song is also written in GarageBand,\. but
I composed it much more recently.\. I decided to return to
GarageBand to write the Blacksmith's song for the sake of
being thematic.
While on this topic,\. I've also got a story about the track
that plays in the final part of "The Nightmare Sequence",
when you collect all the pieces of your sword in the dream
and can continue shooting the Nightmare.
That song is a remix of another song that I wrote many
years ago.\. I wrote the original in GarageBand on my
iPod, and only composed it for piano.
When remixing it,\. I added more instrumentation than just
piano,\. but tried not to stray too much from my original
vision.\. I trusted that my younger self knew what he was
doing.
Frog Town
Time for some background information.\. Back in high
school,\. I was the piano player for the school's jazz
band.\. I was interested in composing back then and
wanted to try composing a piece for a big group.
The band director was really cool about it and wanted to
see what I could come up with.\. My first attempt at
composing a score for jazz band was a complete flop.\.
We looked at it once, and then never again.
But I didn't let that stop me from composing.\. I decided
to try again.\. The holiday season was approaching so I
took some time to compose a simple, winter-themed shuffle.\.
I called the song "Snow Day".
This song was much more well-received by my band director.\.
Eventually,\. the jazz band even performed it at one of
their winter concerts.
And so I made an 8-bit arrangement of Snow Day to play in
Frog Town.\. I used the familiar tune "Jingle Bells" in
the original piece.\. I replaced "Jingle Bells" with
Henriko's theme in the 8-bit version.

Green Light Puzzles
Remember the green light puzzles that Henriko had to do?\.
During testing,\. one of the testers, aka my sister, felt
the green light puzzles weren't challenging enough.
I didn't want to make the first two any harder, though.\.
So I added a really hard one in the basement of the Ocean
Palace.\. You're guess is as good as mine as to finding a
good strategy to solve it.
But I'll admit,\. it's not perfect.\. Sometimes, if you
jump around enough times, the puzzle will decide that it
has been solved even though all the lights have not been
lit up.\. So now you know you can cheese that puzzle.
I'm not sure what's happening with that puzzle.\. I've
looked at the code and I can't find any errors.\. Maybe
it's just the way I programmed it?\. I could probably
improve it somehow.
If I can ever find a way to fix that puzzle,\. I'll release
the fix in a future update for the game.\. Until then,\.
the puzzle is going to be slightly easier to solve.
Side-View to Front-View
For one part of this game,\. I wanted to switch from side
view to front view as a small nod to another popular RPG.\.
I tried doing this myself with the help of a little script,\.
and it seemed to work at first.
I programmed it so that when you entered Shady Cave,\. it
would switch to Front-View, and when you exited Shady Cave,
it would switch back to Side-View.
But upon further testing,\. it appeared that if you entered
the cave, saved, quit the game, and then re-entered the
game,\. the game would have reverted back to Side-View.
I went to find solutions for this online and found this
plugin by Shaz that did exactly what I envisioned. So I
used Shaz's plugin in my game instead of doing it myself.\.
Shoutouts to Shaz!
I did, however, use script to change the second battle with
Garskamar to a Time Progress battle rather than a Turn-based
one.\. And that worked all right.\. Probably only because
you can't save and quit during a battle.
The Puzzle
By "the puzzle",\. I mean the "10,000 piece blacked-out
puzzle" that Garskamar tries to make you do in the castle.\.
Originally that was going to be a joke,\. but I wanted to go
one step further and actually make the puzzle completable.
Here's the algorithm I used:\. If I needed to complete a
10,000 piece puzzle where all the pieces were black, I
would take one piece of the puzzle, and then compare it
with other pieces until I found a match.
Then I would do the same for another puzzle piece, and so
on, until the puzzle was complete.\. The pool of pieces
decreases by one each time you find a match as well,\. so
finding matches will be slightly easier as time goes on.
For those of you studying computer science like I am,\.
I would say that this algorithm has a time complexity of
O(n^2).\. n in this case being 10,000.\. It's not very
good, but it's the best solution I could come up with.
But would you believe it?\. When testing the puzzle,\. I
discovered that I had programmed the algorithm wrong!\.
It's actually easier to find matching pieces compared to
the algorithm I relayed to you.
Instead of fixing it, however, I decided to leave it as is.\.
Though it wouldn't take you as long, it would still take
a REALLY long time.
Here's some math for you. Let's say that the time it
took you to compare a piece to another piece was five
seconds.\. The worst case scenario of a puzzle with
10,000 pieces would be the summation of 10,000.
The summation of 10,000 equals 50,005,000. That number
multiplied by 5 seconds is 250,025,000 seconds.\. That
many seconds is ~4,167,083 minutes. ~69,451 hours.\.
The longest time it would take you to solve that 10,000
piece puzzle while being able to compare pieces every five
seconds is about 7.93 years.
Though I also programmed the puzzle so that your party
members can help too,\. so dividing the work between four
people,\. it would take you only about two years in the
worst case.
But with the programming error I made,\. it shouldn't take
you YEARS to complete the puzzle.\. It might take several
hours,\. but not anywhere close to years. And I think I'm
going to keep it that way.
I don't want someone to make it a goal to complete the
puzzle,\. but then never be able to complete it because
of the monumental amount of time it would take.
I don't see anyone actually seriously doing that anyway.\.
At least,\. I hope not.
The Most Difficult Thing
The most difficult thing to program?\. The Nightmare
battle sequence, for sure.\. The Minimon battle was a
close second,\. but the Nightmare battle was definitely
the most challenging thing to program.
Before I get into that,\. the Minimon battle itself could
have probably used some more debugging.\. If you mess
around enough,\. you'll find something off about the
battle.\. But it works well enough for now.
The Nightmare battle is when you have to fight the LEACH
Nightmare in the final dream sequence of the game.\. This
battle took me two days of serious grind-programming to
really get right.
It was the part of the game I experimented with the most.\.
Instead of a normal turn-based battle, it's a battle on the
map itself where you can shoot the Nightmare with your
sword while dodging its attacks.
The Nightmare has 50 HP and four different attacks.\. It
moves before each attack and picks an attack at random
every time it moves.\. For the second phase,\. it combines
three of its attacks for a combo attack.
The Nightmare can even sense when you're on the left or
right of it and will rush you if you get too close.
I wasn't going to add a second phase at first,\. but then
the idea for the combo attack struck me and I couldn't
resist trying to make it happen.\. I think it was all
worth it in the end.
I won't go into any details about HOW I programmed all of
that,\. but yeah,\. it was tough work.\. But again, it was
worth it.\. Something worth doing is worth overdoing, as
they say.
Overall Experience
This is where I give you my review of RPG Maker as a game
development tool.\. I used RPG Maker MZ to make this game.\.
I'm not sure what this version has that other versions
don't,\. but it's the one I bought, so it's the one I used.
It was definitely easy to learn how to use.\. And it
gradually got easier as I kept developing.\. And I could
definitely see how bigger developers could use it to make
their game stand out from all the "normal RPG Maker" games.
But I didn't feel like I could make my game "stand out"
right now,\. so you got to see a lot of RPG Maker assets
during your playthrough.\. Maybe someday I'll come back
and give Hero's Advent a new coat of paint.\. We'll see.
Though I'm not sure if I'll continue developing any big
games like this with RPG Maker.\. Programming with RPG
Maker almost feels like cheating in a way.
Somebody already wrote most of the important code for me.\.
All I had to do was import my music, my custom sprites, and
program a story from all the tools that were given to me.\.
That's kinda the whole point of RPG Maker, I know.
But I did learn a great deal about the development process
while creating this game.\. There are things I wish I had
known earlier in the process, and there are many things
that I know I could have planned out better.
I want to take everything I learned and do better for my

About 3 years ago,\. I decided that I wanted to challenge
myself.\. I've always wanted to write music for video
games,\. and have messed with some ideas in the past, but
never actually composed anything very meaningful.
Here was the challenge.\. My sister would send me images
or drawings of settings or characters, and I would create
a theme for that setting or character.\. I used FL Studio
to create all of my compositions.
The first piece I wrote during the challenge was
Desertown.\. I composed a total of sixteen musical
pieces for the challenge, experimenting with different
sounds and keys and time signatures.
You can see all the songs I wrote for the challenge at the
artist's house at the top left of Desertown.\. I would have
put them here,\. but I had already programmed that house
and decided it would be a better place for them.
After the challenge was over, I was inspired to keep writing
music.\. After composing a few more battle themes,\. I toyed
with the idea of developing my own video game based on the
music I composed for each setting and character.
For some reason, I had downloaded RPG Maker MZ to my
computer.\. I guess I thought it might be fun to play
around with as an elementary game developing engine.
I went through the tutorial for the software,\. figured
out how everything worked together,\. and realized that
I could definitely make something cool with it.\. All I
needed was a story.
I suddenly found myself typing up a script.\. I worked on
it hours a day for about three days.\. I wanted it to be a
little serious, but also lighthearted and self-aware.\. It
had a basic plot,\. but I was proud of what I wrote.
After that I started the development process.\. I grossly
underestimated the amount of time it would take me to
develop my vision, though.\. At first,\. I calculated that
I could finish developing the game within three months.
And perhaps that could theoretically be possible if I never
had to sleep, eat, work, attend university, visit my family,
and was just a machine that could work nonstop for three
months straight.
No,\. this game took me over two years to finish in its
entirety.\. I didn't work on it every day during that two
years,\. but I seriously had to have put thousands of
hours into its development time.
During the challenge, my sister gave me pictures of two
cartoon animals that I thought I could be turned into
good party members that would join the player.\. Those
animals became Henriko and \N[4].
I decided to do a twist on a familiar trope.\. You know how
RPGs usually have one or two animals mixed in with a crew
of human characters?\. For my RPG, there would be one human,\.
and the rest of the party would be animals.
That means I needed a third animal character that would
join with the player.\. I had been playing a lot of
Animal Crossing that summer.\. It was the perfect game
to relax with during the whole COVID pandemic freakout.
My favorite villager in Animal Crossing is Mathilda the
kangaroo.\. So I thought, "what the heck? I'll just make
the other animal a kangaroo villager." So against my better
judgment, I started spriting a bunch of bootleg kangaroos.
I pretty much copied Nintendo's homework. I colored them
differently from their AC counterparts and gave them
different names,\. but you can obviously tell that
Kate is Kitt,\. Sabrina is Sylvia,\. et cetera.
If any problems arise from what I've done,\. like if
Nintendo's ninjas come after me,\. I won't fight them.\.
I'll just take the game back and redesign the kangaroos
so that they're somewhat more original.
Anyway,\. the kangaroo was the third animal character.\.
I thought they were a good fit.\. They matched the other
character's cuteness factors well.
But that wasn't enough for me.\. I wanted to challenge
myself to take it one step further.\. I gave the player
the option to choose from one of three different kangaroos
depending on which kangaroos house they stayed at.
And I didn't want them to be animals just for the sake of
being animals.\. I gave them special abilities that made
use of what their animal's species were known for.
For example, there are certain areas where Henriko had to
leap across green squares to solve a puzzle,\. and several
small holes that \N[3] could send little \N[5] through.\.
Best I could do for the wizard was burning trees.
I created all of the sprites for the frogs, the kangaroos,
and the wizard.\. Character sprites, face sprites, and battle
sprites.\. I created eight player characters in RPG Maker's

For the enemy monsters,\. I took a lot of inspiration

I created all of the sprites for the Benefic Four, The

I had already composed Hygluk's battle theme, Squidusa's

I bet you're wondering about The Shadow Thief, aren't you?\.
I loved the Mario & Luigi series growing up, and I was

So I wanted to give the Shadow Thief, arguably the best

Although,\. at the time of me writing this,\. the remake

I think all I did was worth it in the end.

That aside,\. I think I made a pretty cool game.
And it's free!\. I don't want to charge anything for my
first amateur passion project game. By the way,\. if you
were forced to spend any money to download this game,\.
you were scammed.
But even though I think the game is cool,\. I'm not the
judge.\. That title goes to you, the player.\. What did

It's not perfect.\. I'm sure there are some bugs that I

And now,\. I'm finally happy to say that I am done with

Frog Town
Time for some background information.\. Back in high
school,\. I was the piano player for the school's jazz
band.\. I was interested in composing back then and
wanted to try composing a piece for a big group.
The band director was really cool about it and wanted to
see what I could come up with.\. My first attempt at
composing a score for jazz band was a complete flop.\.
We looked at it once, and then never again.
But I didn't let that stop me from composing.\. I decided
to try again.\. The holiday season was approaching so I
took some time to compose a simple, winter-themed shuffle.\.
I called the song "Snow Day".
This song was much more well-received by my band director.\.
Eventually,\. the jazz band even performed it at one of

Green Light Puzzles
Remember the green light puzzles that Henriko had to do?\.
During testing,\. one of the testers, aka my sister, felt
the green light puzzles weren't challenging enough.
I didn't want to make the first two any harder, though.\.
So I added a really hard one in the basement of the Ocean
Palace.\. You're guess is as good as mine as to finding a
good strategy to solve it.
But I'll admit,\. it's not perfect.\. Sometimes, if you
jump around enough times, the puzzle will decide that it
has been solved even though all the lights have not been
lit up.\. So now you know you can cheese that puzzle.
I'm not sure what's happening with that puzzle.\. I've
looked at the code and I can't find any errors.\. Maybe
it's just the way I programmed it?\. I could probably
improve it somehow.
If I can ever find a way to fix that puzzle,\. I'll release
the fix in a future update for the game.\. Until then,\.
the puzzle is going to be slightly easier to solve.
Side-View to Front-View
For one part of this game,\. I wanted to switch from side
view to front view as a small nod to another popular RPG.\.
I tried doing this myself with the help of a little script,\.
and it seemed to work at first.
I programmed it so that when you entered Shady Cave,\. it
would switch to Front-View, and when you exited Shady Cave,
it would switch back to Side-View.
But upon further testing,\. it appeared that if you entered
the cave, saved, quit the game, and then re-entered the
game,\. the game would have reverted back to Side-View.
I went to find solutions for this online and found this
plugin by Shaz that did exactly what I envisioned. So I
used Shaz's plugin in my game instead of doing it myself.\.
Shoutouts to Shaz!
I did, however, use script to change the second battle with
Garskamar to a Time Progress battle rather than a Turn-based
one.\. And that worked all right.\. Probably only because
you can't save and quit during a battle.
The Puzzle
By "the puzzle",\. I mean the "10,000 piece blacked-out
puzzle" that Garskamar tries to make you do in the castle.\.
Originally that was going to be a joke,\. but I wanted to go
one step further and actually make the puzzle completable.
Here's the algorithm I used:\. If I needed to complete a
10,000 piece puzzle where all the pieces were black, I
would take one piece of the puzzle, and then compare it
with other pieces until I found a match.
Then I would do the same for another puzzle piece, and so
on, until the puzzle was complete.\. The pool of pieces
decreases by one each time you find a match as well,\. so
finding matches will be slightly easier as time goes on.
For those of you studying computer science like I am,\.
I would say that this algorithm has a time complexity of
O(n^2).\. n in this case being 10,000.\. It's not very
good, but it's the best solution I could come up with.
But would you believe it?\. When testing the puzzle,\. I
discovered that I had programmed the algorithm wrong!\.
It's actually easier to find matching pieces compared to
the algorithm I relayed to you.
Instead of fixing it, however, I decided to leave it as is.\.
Though it wouldn't take you as long, it would still take
a REALLY long time.
Here's some math for you. Let's say that the time it
took you to compare a piece to another piece was five
seconds.\. The worst case scenario of a puzzle with
10,000 pieces would be the summation of 10,000.
The summation of 10,000 equals 50,005,000. That number
multiplied by 5 seconds is 250,025,000 seconds.\. That
many seconds is ~4,167,083 minutes. ~69,451 hours.\.
The longest time it would take you to solve that 10,000
piece puzzle while being able to compare pieces every five
seconds is about 7.93 years.
Though I also programmed the puzzle so that your party
members can help too,\. so dividing the work between four
people,\. it would take you only about two years.
But with the programming error I made,\. it shouldn't take
you YEARS to complete the puzzle.\. It might take several
hours,\. but not anywhere close to years. And I think I'm
going to keep it that way.
I don't want someone to make it a goal to complete the
puzzle,\. but then never be able to complete it because
of the monumental amount of time it would take.
I don't see anyone actually seriously doing that anyway.\.
At least,\. I hope not.
The Most Difficult Thing
The most difficult thing to program?\. The Nightmare
battle sequence, for sure.\. The Minimon battle was a
close second,\. but the Nightmare battle was definitely
the most challenging thing to program.
Before I get into that,\. the Minimon battle itself could
have probably used some more debugging.\. If you mess
around enough,\. you'll find something off about the
battle.\. But it works well enough for now.
The Nightmare battle is when you have to fight the LEACH
Nightmare in the final dream sequence of the game.\. This
battle took me two days of serious grind-programming to
really get right.
It was the part of the game I experimented with the most.\.
Instead of a normal turn-based battle, it's a battle on the
map itself where you can shoot the Nightmare with your
sword while dodging its attacks.
The Nightmare has 50 HP and four different attacks.\. It
moves before each attack and picks an attack at random
every time it moves.\. For the second phase,\. it combines
three of its attacks for a combo attack.
The Nightmare can even sense when you're on the left or
right of it and will rush you if you get too close.
I wasn't going to add a second phase at first,\. but then
the idea for the combo attack struck me and I couldn't
resist trying to make it happen.\. I think it was all
worth it in the end.
I won't go into any details about HOW I programmed all of
that,\. but yeah,\. it was tough work.\. But again, it was
worth it.\. Something worth doing is worth overdoing, as
they say.
Overall Experience
This is where I give you my review of RPG Maker as a game
development tool.\. I used RPG Maker MZ to make this game.\.
I'm not sure what this version has that other versions
don't,\. but it's the one I bought, so it's the one I used.
It was definitely easy to learn how to use.\. And it
gradually got easier as I kept developing.\. And I could
definitely see how bigger developers could use it to make
their game stand out from all the "normal RPG Maker" games.
But I didn't feel like I could make my game "stand out"
right now,\. so you got to see a lot of RPG Maker assets
during your playthrough.\. Maybe someday I'll come back
and give Hero's Advent a new coat of paint.\. We'll see.
Though I'm not sure if I'll continue developing any big
games like this with RPG Maker.\. Programming with RPG
Maker almost feels like cheating in a way.
Somebody already wrote most of the important code for me.\.
All I had to do was import my music, my custom sprites, and
program a story from all the tools that were given to me.\.
That's kinda the whole point of RPG Maker, I know.
But I did learn a great deal about the development process
while creating this game.\. There are things I wish I had
known earlier in the process, and there are many things
that I know I could have planned out better.
I want to take everything I learned and do better for my
next project.\. I think I'll take a break from RPG Maker
and experiment with other game development tools.
